description: This course is concerned with how and why people behave as consumers. Its goals are to: (1) provide conceptual understanding of consumer behavior, (2) provide experience in the application of buyer behavior concepts to marketing management decisions and social policy decision-making; and (3) to develop analytical capability in using behavioral research.
name: CONSUMER BEHAVIOR

values.comments:
This course is concerned with how and why people behave as consumers. Its goals are: 1) to provide conceptual understanding of consumer behavior, 2) to provide experience in applying consumer behavior concepts to marketing management and social policy decision-making, and 3) to develop analytical capability in using behavioral research.

Many students enjoyed the class content even though most claimed that is was very similar to a psychology course and would have preferred more marketing aspects. One student specifically said that the class “too often felt like a psychological anecdote class, with not enough applications of course concepts to actual marketing.” Others, though, claimed that this class “combined the interest and glamour of psychology with applicable business concepts.” Several students also mentioned that the guest speakers added a great element to the class.

Students said that Professor Small was always accessible, but there were mixed responses on her lecturing style. Some said she stimulated student interest and was a skillful lecturer, while others claimed that she needed to have “a stronger grasp on course content.” Another commented that “a bit more direction in the discussions would be appreciated.” Many claimed that Professor Small was strict on attendance, especially regarding students attending the lecture in which they were registered.

Students noted that the reading assignments were manageable and quite useful. They also mentioned that the lecture materials were pertinent. However, many students claimed that while the tests throughout the semester were not difficult, the final exam was challenging and the material covered was unexpected. One student commented that overall the curve was generous in comparison to other Wharton classes. The class requires regular attendance, exams, case write-ups, and class participation.
